title: Pacific Northwest's ‘forest gardens’ were deliberately planted by Indigenous people

last_post.content:
Also a lot of the Planting Trees Is Cool concept is tied to the (very racist) idea that forests are only "pure" without human involvement, which goes against Indigenous land engineering going back millennia. We need humans in forests.

I don't want to speak over Indigenous leaders there, but tribes are only just now starting to control their own forests again. And historical Indigenous food forests in the PNW are shown to be *more diverse* than areas around them, even after being left alone for decades: https://www.science.org/content/article/pacific-northwest-s-forest-gardens-were-deliberately-planted-indigenous-people

And yes, back to the point, monocultures *are* bad. But also "monoculture" planting hasn't been a Thing outside of farmed trees since at least the 1970s. Nowadays trees are chosen for restoration work in *mixes* to match the planned mature forest, usually with bush species to create an understory for the trees to grow around and with for protection. So if you're going to make that argument, ask yourself where it's coming from, because it's not likely good.

Everyone has the moment when they realized there might be something wrong with Scott Adams. For me it was in 1997. I know this because I filed the strips away as a reminder. This is one of them, tracked down on the official web site.

Scott Adams allegedly worked as a programmer, so surely he must have heard of the Halting Problem? It's the idea that you might want to write some software that can analyze other software and determine if it will successfully run to completion. Alan Turing proved it's impossible to do that. So, it is absolutely possible to prove that something can't be done with software.

The Halting Problem is literally CS101 stuff. Did he ignore it so he could go on an anti-science rant, or was he in Dunning-Kruger territory even back then?

https://dilbert.com/strip/1997-12-24 #ScottAdams

title: GitHub - chainsawriot/rang: Reconstructing R computational environments

last_post.content:
Excited to introduce the #Rstats package rang (developed by @chainsawriot and me). The pkg helps to reconstruct historical R environments to make old code run again (ie make it reproducible!). So far, it supports all code back to R 2.1.0 (2005!)
https://github.com/chainsawriot/rang


The package is an Rchaeological tool to ensure reproducibility retrospectively. You can also use rang to make your current projects future proof, but pkgs like renv or groundhog are better suited for this task.

title: Sci-fi becomes real as renowned magazine closes submissions due to AI writers

I agree that a focus on product over process is often corrosive to learning,¹ but it seems that traditional grading regimes do more to promote this than generative AI. That seems more inline w/ their stated goals. 🤔

title: Learning and Developing with SQL · It Will Never Work in Theory

last_post.content: What do SE researchers study? One finding is that, "…SQL development tasks have a significantly longer time-to-completion than SQL-unrelated tasks and require significantly more code changes." Another is that, "…students are hindered in their query formulation process by mismanaging complexity through writing overly elaborate queries…" Findings like these can and should shape how we do code reviews and how we teach database courses. https://neverworkintheory.org/2023/02/25/learning-and-developing-with-sql.html
